awd_titl_txt: Modification of lithospheric structure via subduction, terrane accretion, and rifting: A case study beneath Connecticut
awd_abstract_narration:
The bedrock geology of the eastern United States is extraordinary in its complexity. This complexity reflects a range of plate tectonic processes that have affected eastern North America over geologic time. These processes include the formation and breakup of supercontinents, the accretion of new landmasses onto the continental edge, and widespread volcanic activity due to subduction and continental rifting. The state of Connecticut, though relatively compact in area, represents a prime opportunity to study this range of fundamental Earth processes. This is because Connecticut's geology reflects several phases of mountain building and terrane accretion during the formation of the Appalachian Mountains and the Pangea supercontinent, as well as the later breakup of Pangea and the formation of the Atlantic Ocean basin. This project will use data from an array of 15 seismic stations deployed across northern Connecticut to study the deep structure of the crust and mantle beneath the state, using recordings of seismic waves from distant earthquakes. The team will use images of this deep structure to answer fundamental questions about how supercontinents are formed and break up, as well as how plate tectonic processes such as subduction, rifting, and terrane accretion affect the evolution of the crust and upper mantle. The project includes a component of outreach to high school science teachers, enabling teachers to spend one week in the field collecting data and learning about Connecticut geology, as well as developing a classroom exercise that uses seismic data from the project.

The investigators will analyze data from the Seismic Experiment for Imaging Structure beneath Connecticut (SEISConn), a deployment of 15 broadband seismometers in a dense linear array across northern Connecticut. The array occupies a region of the Appalachian Orogen that encompasses a striking variety of accreted terrane structures, as well as the Hartford Basin, a Mesozoic rift structure resulting from the breakup of Pangea. They will apply a suite of imaging techniques to SEISConn data, focusing on the imaging of discontinuity structure, seismic velocity structure, and seismic anisotropy within the crust and lithospheric mantle. The project is motivated by three major science questions: 1) How did episodes of subduction and terrane accretion during Appalachian oogenesis affect crustal and mantle lithospheric structure, and how does present-day deep structure correspond to surface geology? 2) How was the structure of the crust and mantle lithosphere affected by (failed) rifting during the Mesozoic, and how does the structure beneath the Hartford Rift Basin compare to structure across the (ultimately successful) rifted margin of eastern North America? 3) How was the crust and mantle deformed during subduction, terrane accretion, and rifting? This project will apply a range of analysis techniques to SEISConn data, including P-to-S and S-to-P receiver function analysis, ambient noise tomography, wavefield migration imaging, and shear wave splitting. The final phase of the project will involve the testing of specific hypotheses about past tectonic processes that were formulated based on geologic observations. This project will support the continuation of the successful Field Experiences for Science Teachers (FEST) program at Yale, which provides one week of field seismology experience to Connecticut-based high school science teachers.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This project studied the detailed structure of the crust and uppermost mantle beneath southern New England. The bedrock geology of this region is extraordinary in its complexity, and has been shaped by past episodes of subduction, mountain building, the accretion of small continental blocks known as terranes, and supercontinent formation and breakup. It therefore provides an exceptional natural laboratory to study fundamental plate tectonic processes and to understand how they are expressed in the structure of the continental lithosphere (the crust and uppermost part of the mantle).

We used data from the SEISConn experiment, which was a deployment of broadband seismic stations spaced ~10 km apart on an east-west transect across northern Connecticut and Rhode Island. Each seismometer was capable of recording ground motion generated by large earthquakes all over the world. We used these seismic recordings to generate images of the crust and mantle, using techniques that are similar to medical imaging applications such as a CT scan.

We found that the continental lithosphere beneath southern New England is highly complex, similar to the bedrock geology exposed at the surface. We found that the crust is relatively thick (~45 km) beneath the western part of the SEISConn array, beneath older rocks that are part of the stable, long-lived tectonic core of the North American continent. In contrast, the crust is much thinner beneath the younger rocks to the east, units that were accreted onto the edge of North America during the Appalachian mountain building events. We tested several different tectonic models to explain this difference in crustal thickness, and favor a model in which compression and shortening during a phase of mountain building (the Acadian Orogeny) that may have looked similar to the present-day Himalayas reactivated older faults in the lithosphere. We found evidence for several west-dipping structures in the crust and mantle lithosphere that likely correspond to relict structures from past episodes of subduction, helping us to tease apart the complicated tectonic history of the region. We also studied seismic anisotropy, or the directional dependence of seismic wave speeds, because this is an excellent indicator for deformation, strain, and material flow at depth. We found evidence for deformation in the upper mantle that is related to present-day plate motions, as well as layers of anisotropy in the crust and lithospheric mantle that correspond to past tectonic events, including crustal deformation during mountain building. Finally, we compared results from our imaging of the crust and mantle beneath southern New England to results from the same imaging techniques applied to data from the central and southern Appalachian Mountains. We observe significant differences in the structures beneath southern New England and elsewhere in the Appalachians, pointing to a geographically specific set of past tectonic processes that have operated in southern New England and have shaped the lithospheric structure in a unique way.

The broader impacts of our project included the training of a Ph.D. student and several undergraduate students, all of whom gained research and field work experience in the context of a collaborative, multi-disciplinary project. This grant also supported two sessions of the Field Experiences for Science Teachers (FEST) program, which provides one week of field-based research and experiential learning for Connecticut-based high school science teachers. Results from this project were incorporated into several talks aimed at the general public, helping to make the results of this research accessible.
